PROCESS DESCRIPTION: 

Channel Chemical stores Formaldehyde 37% Solution in a 10,000 gallon stainless steel jacketed tank at atmospheric pressure.  The Formaldehyde storage tank is located within a diked concrete tank farm with recovery sumps. Formaldehyde is delivered in bulk by tanker trailers, and is offloaded through 2" chemical hoses to the storage tank.  Displaced vapors travel through a vent line to a caustic scrubber.  For processing use in the plant, 300 gallon totes are filled from the formaldehyde tank by a 2" discharge line with two shut-off valves.  These totes are moved by forklift and placed on scales, connected to air operated pumps, and pumped to glass-lined reactors for batch processing. 



PREVENTION PROGRAM DESCRIPTION:

Channel Chemical has an RMP that follows the requirements for a Program 3 Prevention Program due to NAICS code 32599.  Specifically, the RMP includes:



(Section 68.65) Process Safety Information: 

A compilation of written process safety information is provided for each regulated facility process to enable supervisors and employees to identify and understand the process hazards. This information is provided through process batch sheets, available SDS?s, and reminders posted in daily production schedules. 



(Section 68.67) Process Hazard Analysis: 

As a "toll" or custom chemical manufacturer, Channel makes products using customer proprietary processes and raw materials.  Customer processes are developed, tested, and analyzed for hazards before being passed on to Channel.  New processes are sometimes demonstrated by customer personnel at Channel, who supervise Channel personnel running the processes until released to Channel for regular production.  The Director of Operations is responsible for regular reviews of safety and training practices, equipment safety, employee conformity to process health and safety rules, and general process procedures.  Changes are made on a regular basis or as necessary. 



(Section 68.69) Operating Procedures: 

Process safety instructions and guidelines are provided by customers, and are reviewed with employees and made a part of Process Outlines used in making the various products.  General safety instructions are covered in the Employee Manual, and specific written instructions are made part of employee training, and provided in cases of more complicated equipment in check lists at the Operators Station.



(Section 68.71) Training: 

All employees (including Operators, Operator Assistants, and Helpers) that are expected to have any contact with any hazardous chemical at Channel Chemical are instructed in the safety and health hazards of those chemicals and the processes in which those chemicals will be used. The purpose of this training is for the protection of themselves, their fellow employees and the citizens of the nearby communities. Training is conducted in compliance with 1910.1200, the Hazard Communication standard.



(Section 68.73) Mechanical Integrity: 

Channel Chemical?s mechanical integrity program involves daily visual inspections and weekly equipment reviews. This program has proven successful over the several years in use due to the company's small number of equipment pieces. It has served to ensure safe process operation.  



(Section 68.75) Management of Change: 

Temporary and permanent changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and facilities are managed to ensure effective process safety management. Process changes include all modifications to equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions.  As a toll manufacturer, these changes are almost always proposed and/or initiated by the customer.  They are then reviewed and authorized by both the customer and Channel's Director Of Operations prior to implementing the change.



(Section 68.77) Pre-Startup Review: 

Prior to the start up of any new production process Channel goes through several steps to ensure a safe and confident process start up.  These steps include:

1) Several ?paper? reviews of the process with the customer and their technical experts; and then an internal review with all departments at Channel. 

2) Prior to running a pilot batch of the new process, we have a ?roundtable? review with customer representatives on site, and then a walk through out in the plant including Channel department managers. 

3) We then complete a safety review out in the plant with the customer to ensure the planned equipment set up is adequate and safe for the planned production run.  



(Section 68.79) Compliance Audits: 

Channel?s management is responsible for reviewing its audit compliance with OSHA?s process safety management standard 29 CFR 1910.119 at least once every three years. Channel conducts this review using Customer Process Managers and  Environmental Consultants.  



(Section 68.81) Incident Investigation: 

Channel Chemical believes any incident that results in or could reasonably have resulted in a release of hazardous chemicals is a very serious matter.  Those involved in the incident are interviewed to determine why the incident took place and what can be done in the future to prevent the same incident from occurring.  When warranted, the toll customer is contacted for additional input regarding the situation.  



(Section 68.83) Employee Participation: 

Employee participation is a high priority at Channel Chemical.  From the "Open Door Policy" and "Suggestions" sections in Channels Employee Handbook to special strategy meetings, employees are always encouraged to provide input, concerns, suggestions, and strategy comments.  Channel is especially interested in the areas of process safety, employee health, and the protection of the environment.



(Section 68.85) Hot Work Permit: 

Channel controls non-routine work performed in process areas in a consistent manner. The hazards identified involving the work to be accomplished is communicated to those performing the work and to operating personnel whose work could affect the safety of the process. No hot work is allowed in production areas without a authorized permit.



(Section 68.87) Contractors: 

A basic screening process has been established for hiring contractors to perform work in and around Channel manufacturing processes that involve highly hazardous chemicals. The screening process is designed to ensure that the contractors hired or used can accomplish their assigned tasks without compromising the safety and health of employees at the facility. The screening program involves verbally obtaining information on the contractor?s experience and safety practices on similar job sites.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

In the course of manufacturing products, Channel Chemical receives, stores and handles more than 100 different chemicals. The safety and health of our employees is our number one priority at the plant, followed closely by the health and safety of our neighbors and the protection of the environment.



To minimize any risk to people and environment Channel follows state and federal guidelines in the storage and handling of these chemicals. Channel spill prevention policies include plant inspections every working shift, securing valves on storage vessels, and continual visual monitoring during the transfer of all chemicals. The company also maintains written emergency response plans in the event that there is a spill or accidental release. The plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.



THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Channel Chemical Corporation is located in the Bernard Bayou Industrial park in Harrison County, Mississippi. The company is located on an 11-acre parcel of land stretching between Seaway Road and Bernard Bayou. 



Channel handles only one chemical that is considered hazardous in quantities above threshold limits according to the List of Regulated Toxic Substances of 40CFR part 68.130. This chemical is Formaldehyde Solution 37%. The facility receives a tank truck of Formaldehyde Solution (4,900 gallons) an average of twice a month.  Channel stores a maximum of 5,000 gallons of the solution in a bulk storage tank, which is located in an outside diked storage tank farm. It also stores two or three back up totes (300 gallons each) of the solution.  



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM/CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

This manufacturing facility is in compliance with state and federal laws and programs concerning the prevention of chemical spills including SWPPP, EPA's Accidental R

elease Prevention Rule, and OSHA's Process Safety Management rules. In addition, operators are well versed in the proper handling and monitoring of Formaldehyde Solution whenever it is used in a manufacturing process. All of Channel's employees receive regular training in spill prevention and spill clean up.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

According to the requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program, Formaldehyde Solution is the only chemical on Channel's plant site that falls within the parameters of this Risk Management Plan--meaning that the chemical is on the Hazardous Chemical List (CAA 112(r)), and that Channel stores it in a quantity above the List's "Threshold Quantity."   There has been no accidental release related to Formaldehyde Solution in the past five years according to the definitions provided in 40 CFR Section 68.42.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Channel's Emergency Response Program is based on taking all actions necessary to reduce the threat of exposure to its employees, surrounding neighbors, and to the environment.  

Included in these efforts:

--Regular updates to the local fire department and local emergency response department including an updated list of chemicals stored on Channel's site, an updated map of where the chemicals are stored, and a copy of any SDS's for new chemicals stored on site are made available to them as needed.

--Channel also tries to take representatives of the local fire department on tour of the plant whenever practical, and whenever requested by the local fire departments. This allows the department personnel to become familiar with the plant layout and ask questions about the plant and the chemicals stored here. It also allows Channel to get feedback from the fire department on improvements it might make to make the plant site safer or more accessible to emergency personnel. In addition, the fire department also trains Channel employees in the correct use of fire extinguishers on the plant site.

--Channel e

mployees go through regular safety training and emergency policies and procedures. Personnel also go through drills including what to do when an employee is injured and when/how to evacuate the plant in an emergency.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

--Channel will continue to bring in outside trainers and consultants to educate employees and management on proper precautions and procedures related to personal safety and the safety of others and the environment.

--Channel is investigating the merits of adding cameras, monitors, and alarms that will help ensure the safety of the employees and the environment.
